questions.stem: A school health program is important because:
options: School children are characterized by slow physiologic and psychosocial changes.
School children represent about 40% of the Egyptian population.
Its interventions affect the quality of life of many generations.
School children suffer the highest mortality.
questions.explanation: Interventions in school health programs have a long-lasting impact, influencing the health and well-being of future generations[cite: 178].

questions.stem: Malnutrition problems among school children include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: According to the provided text, iron deficiency, protein-energy deficiency, and Vitamin A deficiency are listed as problems, making Vitamin D deficiency the correct exception[cite: 178].

questions.stem: Nutrition care for school children includes all of the following EXCEPT:
options: A feeding program should include 1/3 of total daily calories.
The school canteen should avoid unhealthy foods.
Implementation of the principles of food sanitation.
A feeding program should include 1/4 of daily protein requirements.
questions.explanation: The text specifies that feeding programs should cover one-third of daily calories, but does not mention a specific fraction for protein requirements, making this the correct exception[cite: 178].

questions.stem: Which of the following is NOT an example of an intervention for the specific prevention of diseases in a school health program?
options: Chemoprophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis in case of outbreaks
questions.explanation: While vaccinations like MMR and meningococcal are part of school health, DPT is typically completed in early childhood before school age, making it the exception in this context[cite: 178].

questions.stem: The most frequent nutritional problems among school children are:
options: Vitamin A deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and riboflavin deficiency
Vitamin A deficiency, rickets, and riboflavin deficiency
Vitamin C deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and riboflavin deficiency
Vitamin K deficiency, B12 deficiency anemia, and riboflavin deficiency
questions.explanation: The text identifies Vitamin A deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and riboflavin (B2) deficiency as the most common nutritional issues in this age group[cite: 178].

questions.stem: Protein and energy deficiency among school children can result in retarded growth and wasting.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]Adequate protein and energy are crucial for growth and development during the school years, and a deficiency can lead to poor growth outcomes[cite: 178].

questions.stem: Rheumatic heart disease is the most common heart disease that affects school children.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]Rheumatic heart disease, a complication of untreated streptococcal infections, is a significant cause of cardiac issues in school-aged children in many parts of the world[cite: 178].

questions.stem: Dental caries among schoolchildren can be due to a lack of teeth hygiene, excess sweet intake, and fluorine deficiency.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]These three factors—poor hygiene, high sugar consumption, and inadequate fluoride exposure—are the primary contributors to the development of dental caries in children[cite: 178].

questions.stem: A school feeding program should include at least one-third of the total daily required calories.
questions.explanation: True. [cite_start]This is a standard guideline to ensure that school meals make a significant contribution to the child's overall daily nutritional needs[cite: 178].
